Identification.LongTitle: An Act respecting corrections and the conditional release and detention of offenders and to establish the office of Correctional Investigator

Provision.Text: Her Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate and House of Commons of Canada, enacts as follows:

Section.Text: This Act may be cited as the Corrections and Conditional Release Act.

Subsection.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: Commissioner means the Commissioner of Corrections appointed pursuant to subsection 6(1);
contraband means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an intoxicant,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a weapon or a component thereof, ammunition for a weapon, and anything that is designed to kill, injure or disable a person or that is altered so as to be capable of killing, injuring or disabling a person, when possessed without prior authorization,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explosive or a bomb or a component thereof,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: currency over any applicable prescribed limit, when possessed without prior authorization, and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any item not described in paragraphs (a) to (d) that could jeopardize the security of a penitentiary or the safety of persons, when that item is possessed without prior authorization;

Definition.Text: day parole has the same meaning as in Part II;
inmate means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is in a penitentiary pursuant to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a sentence, committal or transfer to penitentiary, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a condition imposed by the Parole Board of Canada in connection with day parole or statutory release, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who, having been sentenced, committed or transferred to penitentiary,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is temporarily outside penitentiary by reason of a temporary absence or work release authorized under this Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is temporarily outside penitentiary for reasons other than a temporary absence, work release, parole or statutory release, but is under the direction or supervision of a staff member or of a person authorized by the Service;

Definition.Text: institutional head, in relation to a penitentiary, means the person who is normally in charge of the penitentiary;

intoxicant means a substance that, if taken into the body, has the potential to impair or alter judgment, behaviour or the capacity to recognize reality or meet the ordinary demands of life, but does not include caffeine, nicotine or any authorized medication used in accordance with directions given by a staff member or a registered health care professional;
long-term supervision means long-term supervision ordered under subsection 753(4), 753.01(5) or (6) or 753.1(3) or subparagraph 759(3)(a)(i) of the Criminal Code;
Minister means the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness;
offender means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an inmate, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who, having been sentenced, committed or transferred to penitentiary, is outside penitentiary

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by reason of parole or statutory release,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: pursuant to an agreement referred to in subsection 81(1), or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: pursuant to a court order;

Definition.Text: parole has the same meaning as in Part II;
penitentiary means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a facility of any description, including all lands connected therewith, that is operated, permanently or temporarily, by the Service for the care and custody of inmates, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any place declared to be a penitentiary pursuant to section 7;

Definition.Text: prescribed means prescribed by regulation;
provincial parole board has the same meaning as in Part II;
sentence means a sentence of imprisonment and includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a sentence imposed by a foreign entity on a Canadian offender who has been transferred to Canada under the International Transfer of Offenders Act, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a youth sentence imposed under the Youth Criminal Justice Act consisting of a custodial portion and a portion to be served under supervision in the community subject to conditions under paragraph 42(2)(n) of that Act or under conditional supervision under paragraph 42(2)(o), (q) or (r) of that Act;

Definition.Text: Service means the Correctional Service of Canada described in section 5;
staff member means an employee of the Service;
statutory release has the same meaning as in Part II;
unescorted temporary absence has the same meaning as in Part II;
victim, in respect of an offence, means an individual who has suffered physical or emotional harm, property damage or economic loss as the result of the commission of the offence.
visitor means any person other than an inmate or a staff member.
working day means a day on which offices of the federal public administration are generally open in the province in question.

Subsection.Text: Except as otherwise provided by this Part or by regulations made under paragraph 96(b),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: powers, duties and functions that this Part assigns to the Commissioner may only be exercised or performed by the Commissioner or, where the Commissioner is absent or incapacitated or where the office is vacant, by the person acting in the place of the Commissioner; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: powers, duties and functions that this Part assigns to the institutional head may only be exercised or performed by the institutional head or, where the institutional head is absent or incapacitated or where the office is vacant, by the person who, at the relevant time, is in charge of the penitentiary.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Act, any of the following individuals may act on the victim’s behalf if the victim is dead or incapable of acting on their own behalf:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the victim’s spouse, or if the victim is dead, their spouse at the time of death;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the individual who is or was at the time of the victim’s death, cohabiting with them in a conjugal relationship, having so cohabited for a period of at least one year;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a relative or a dependant of the victim;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an individual who has in law or fact custody, or is responsible for the care or support, of the victim; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an individual who has in law or fact custody, or is responsible for the care or support, of a dependant of the victim.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this Act, an individual is not a victim, or entitled to act on a victim’s behalf, in relation to an offence, if the individual is the offender.

Section.MarginalNote: Application to persons subject to long-term supervision order
Section.Text: A person who is required to be supervised by a long-term supervision order is deemed to be an offender for the purposes of this Part, and sections 3, 4, 23 to 27, 55 and 56, subsections 57(2) and 66(3), sections 68, 69, 76, 77 and 79 to 82, paragraph 87(b) and sections 90 and 91 apply, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to the person and to the long-term supervision of that person.
The purpose of the federal correctional system is to contribute to the maintenance of a just, peaceful and safe society by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carrying out sentences imposed by courts through the safe and humane custody and supervision of offenders; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the rehabilitation of offenders and their reintegration into the community as law-abiding citizens through the provision of programs in penitentiaries and in the community.

Section.Text: The protection of society is the paramount consideration for the Service in the corrections process.
The principles that guide the Service in achieving the purpose referred to in section 3 are as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the sentence is carried out having regard to all relevant available information, including the stated reasons and recommendations of the sentencing judge, the nature and gravity of the offence, the degree of responsibility of the offender, information from the trial or sentencing process, the release policies of and comments from the Parole Board of Canada and information obtained from victims, offenders and other components of the criminal justice system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Service enhances its effectiveness and openness through the timely exchange of relevant information with victims, offenders and other components of the criminal justice system and through communication about its correctional policies and programs to victims, offenders and the public;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Service uses measures that are consistent with the protection of society, staff members and offenders and that are limited to only what is necessary and proportionate to attain the purposes of this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: offenders retain the rights of all members of society except those that are, as a consequence of the sentence, lawfully and necessarily removed or restricted;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the Service facilitates the involvement of members of the public in matters relating to the operations of the Service;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: correctional decisions are made in a forthright and fair manner, with access by the offender to an effective grievance procedure;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: correctional policies, programs and practices respect gender, ethnic, cultural and linguistic differences and are responsive to the special needs of women, aboriginal peoples, persons requiring mental health care and other groups;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: offenders are expected to obey penitentiary rules and conditions governing temporary absences, work release, parole, statutory release and long-term supervision and to actively participate in meeting the objectives of their correctional plans, including by participating in programs designed to promote their rehabilitation and reintegration; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: staff members are properly selected and trained and are given

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: appropriate career development opportunities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: good working conditions, including a workplace environment that is free of practices that undermine a person’s sense of personal dignity, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: opportunities to participate in the development of correctional policies and programs.

Section.Text: There shall continue to be a correctional service in and for Canada, to be known as the Correctional Service of Canada, which shall be responsible for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the care and custody of inmates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the provision of programs that contribute to the rehabilitation of offenders and to their successful reintegration into the community;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the preparation of inmates for release;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: parole, statutory release supervision and long-term supervision of offenders; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: maintaining a program of public education about the operations of the Service.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may appoint a person to be known as the Commissioner of Corrections who, under the direction of the Minister, has the control and management of the Service and all matters connected with the Service.
The national headquarters of the Service and the offices of the Commissioner shall be in the National Capital Region described in the schedule to the National Capital Act.
The Commissioner may establish regional headquarters of the Service.

Subject to subsection (3), the Commissioner may, by order, declare any prison as defined in the Prisons and Reformatories Act, or any hospital, to be a penitentiary in respect of any person or class of persons.
Subject to subsection (3), the Governor in Council may, by order, declare any place to be a penitentiary.

No prison, hospital or place administered or supervised under the authority of an Act of the legislature of a province may be declared a penitentiary under subsection (1) or (2) without the approval of an officer designated by the lieutenant governor of that province.

Section.Text: In any proceedings before a court in Canada in which a question arises concerning the location or description of lands alleged to constitute a penitentiary, a certificate purporting to be signed by the Commissioner, setting out the location or description of those lands as constituting a penitentiary, is admissible in evidence and, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, is proof that the lands as located or described in the certificate constitute a penitentiary.
For greater certainty, a person who is an inmate by virtue of subparagraph (b)(ii) of the definition “inmate” in section 2 shall be deemed to be in the lawful custody of the Service.

The Commissioner may in writing designate any staff member, either by name or by class, to be a peace officer, and a staff member so designated has all the powers, authority, protection and privileges that a peace officer has by law in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an offender subject to a warrant or to an order for long-term supervision; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person, while the person is in a penitentiary.

Section.Text: A person who is sentenced, committed or transferred to penitentiary may be received into any penitentiary, and any designation of a particular penitentiary in the warrant of committal is of no force or effect.

Where a person who is sentenced, committed or transferred to penitentiary is at large without lawful authority before the expiration of the sentence according to law and where no alternative means of arrest are available, the institutional head may, by warrant, authorize the apprehension and recommitment of the person to custody in a penitentiary.

In order to better enable a person who has been sentenced to penitentiary or who is required by law to be transferred to penitentiary to file an appeal or attend to personal affairs, such a person shall not be received in penitentiary until the expiration of fifteen days after the day on which the person was sentenced, unless the person agrees to be transferred to a penitentiary before the expiration of those fifteen days.

The institutional head may refuse to receive a person referred to in section 12 into the penitentiary if there is not a certificate signed by a registered health care professional setting out available health information and stating whether or not the person appears to be suffering from a dangerous, infectious or contagious disease.

Subsection.Text: A person who, by virtue of section 12 or 13, is not received into a penitentiary shall be confined in a provincial correctional facility.
The person in charge of the provincial correctional facility to whom a person referred to in subsection (1) is delivered shall, on being presented with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the warrant of committal to penitentiary, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the warrant of committal certified by any judge of a superior or provincial court, by any justice of the peace, or by the clerk of the court in which the person was convicted,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: confine the person in the provincial correctional facility until the person is transferred to penitentiary or released from custody in accordance with law.

Subsection.Text: Notwithstanding any requirement in the Criminal Code or under the Youth Criminal Justice Act that a person be sentenced, committed or transferred to penitentiary, such a person in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador shall not be received in a penitentiary without the approval of an officer designated by the Lieutenant Governor of Newfoundland and Labrador.

A person who, pursuant to subsection (1), is not received in a penitentiary shall be confined in the provincial correctional facility in Newfoundland and Labrador known as Her Majesty’s Penitentiary, and is subject to all the statutes, regulations and rules applicable in that facility.

The Minister may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, enter into an agreement with the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador providing for the payment to the Province of the cost of maintaining persons who are confined pursuant to subsection (2).

The institutional head shall cause a correctional plan to be developed in consultation with the offender as soon as practicable after their reception in a penitentiary. The plan is to contain, among others, the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the level of intervention in respect of the offender’s needs; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: objectives for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the offender’s behaviour, including

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: to conduct themselves in a manner that demonstrates respect for other persons and property,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: to obey penitentiary rules and respect the conditions governing their conditional release, if any,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: their participation in programs, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the meeting of their court-ordered obligations, including restitution to victims or child support.

Subsection.Text: The plan is to be maintained in consultation with the offender in order to ensure that they receive the most effective programs at the appropriate time in their sentence to rehabilitate them and prepare them for reintegration into the community, on release, as a law-abiding citizen.

In making decisions on program selection for — or the transfer or conditional release of — an inmate, the Service shall take into account the offender’s progress towards meeting the objectives of their correctional plan.

Section.Text: The Commissioner may provide offenders with incentives to encourage them to make progress towards meeting the objectives of their correctional plans.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, enter into an agreement with the government of a province for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the confinement in provincial correctional facilities or hospitals in that province of persons sentenced, committed or transferred to penitentiary; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the confinement in penitentiary of persons sentenced or committed to imprisonment for less than two years for offences under any Act of Parliament or any regulations made thereunder.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a person who is confined in a penitentiary pursuant to an agreement entered into under paragraph (1)(b) is, despite section 743.1 of the Criminal Code, subject to all the statutes, regulations and rules applicable in the penitentiary in which the person is confined.
The release date of an offender who is transferred to penitentiary pursuant to an agreement entered into under paragraph (1)(b) shall be determined by crediting against the sentence

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any remission, statutory or earned, standing to the offender’s credit on the day of the transfer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum remission that could have been earned on the balance of the sentence pursuant to the Prisons and Reformatories Act.

Subsection.Text: The institutional head may, subject to section 746.1 of the Criminal Code, subsection 140.3(2) of the National Defence Act and subsection 15(2) of the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act, authorize the temporary absence of an inmate, other than an inmate described in subsection 17.1(1), if the inmate is escorted by a staff member or other person authorized by the institutional head and, in the opinion of the institutional head,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate will not, by reoffending, present an undue risk to society during an absence authorized under this section;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is desirable for the inmate to be absent from the penitentiary for medical or administrative reasons, community service, family contact, including parental responsibilities, personal development for rehabilitative purposes or compassionate reasons;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate’s behaviour while under sentence does not preclude authorizing the absence; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a structured plan for the absence has been prepared.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: The temporary absence may be for an unlimited period if it is authorized for medical reasons or for a period of not more than five days or, with the Commissioner’s approval, for a period of more than five days but not more than 15 days if it is authorized for reasons other than medical reasons.

Subsection.Text: The institutional head may impose, in relation to a temporary absence, any conditions that the institutional head considers reasonable and necessary in order to protect society.
The institutional head may cancel a temporary absence either before or after its commencement.
The institutional head shall give the inmate written reasons for the authorizing, refusal or cancellation of a temporary absence.
In addition to the period authorized for the purposes of a temporary absence, an inmate may be granted the time necessary to travel to and from the place where the absence is authorized to be spent.

Where, pursuant to an agreement under paragraph 16(1)(a), an inmate has been admitted to a hospital operated by a provincial government in which the liberty of patients is normally subject to restrictions, the institutional head may confer on the person in charge of the hospital, for such period and subject to such conditions as the institutional head specifies, any of the institutional head’s powers under this section in relation to that inmate.

Section.MarginalNote: Temporary absences may be approved — exception

Subsection.Text: The Parole Board of Canada may authorize the temporary absence of an inmate who is serving a sentence of imprisonment for life imposed as a minimum punishment and is eligible for day parole if the inmate is escorted by a staff member or other person authorized by the institutional head and the Parole Board of Canada is of the opinion that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate will not, by reoffending, present an undue risk to society during an absence authorized under this section;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is desirable for the inmate to be absent from the penitentiary for administrative reasons, community service, family contact, including parental responsibilities, personal development for rehabilitative purposes or compassionate reasons;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate’s behaviour while under sentence does not preclude authorizing the absence; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a structured plan for the absence has been prepared.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: The temporary absence may be for a period of not more than 15 days.

Subsection.Text: If the Parole Board of Canada authorizes the temporary absence of an inmate under subsection (1) for community service, family contact, including parental responsibilities, or personal development for rehabilitative purposes and the temporary absence is not cancelled because the inmate has breached a condition, the institutional head may authorize that inmate’s subsequent temporary absences with escort if the institutional head is of the opinion that the criteria set out in paragraphs (1)(a) to (d) are met.

If a temporary absence authorized by the institutional head is cancelled because the inmate breached a condition in relation to it, the inmate’s subsequent temporary absence may be authorized only by the Parole Board of Canada.

The Parole Board of Canada or the institutional head, as the case may be, may impose, in relation to a temporary absence that it authorizes, any condition that it considers reasonable and necessary in order to protect society.
The institutional head may cancel a temporary absence that is authorized under this section either before or after its commencement and shall give the inmate written reasons for doing so.
The Parole Board of Canada or the institutional head, as the case may be, shall give the inmate written reasons for authorizing or refusing a temporary absence.

In this section, work release means a structured program of release of specified duration for work or community service outside the penitentiary, under the supervision of a staff member or other person or organization authorized by the institutional head.

Where an inmate is eligible for unescorted temporary absences under Part II or pursuant to section 746.1 of the Criminal Code, subsection 226.1(2) of the National Defence Act or subsection 15(2) of the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act, and, in the opinion of the institutional head,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate will not, by reoffending, present an undue risk to society during a work release,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is desirable for the inmate to participate in a structured program of work or community service in the community,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate’s behaviour while under sentence does not preclude authorizing the work release, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a structured plan for the work release has been prepared,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the institutional head may authorize a work release, for such duration as is fixed by the institutional head, subject to the approval of the Commissioner if the duration is to exceed sixty days.

Subsection.Text: The institutional head may impose, in relation to a work release, any conditions that the institutional head considers reasonable and necessary in order to protect society.
The institutional head may suspend or cancel a work release either before or after its commencement.
The institutional head shall give the inmate written reasons for the authorizing, refusal, suspension or cancellation of a work release.

Where a work release is suspended or cancelled after its commencement, the institutional head may cause a warrant in writing to be issued authorizing the apprehension and recommitment to custody of the inmate.

Where an inmate dies or suffers serious bodily injury, the Service shall, whether or not there is an investigation under section 20, forthwith investigate the matter and report thereon to the Commissioner or to a person designated by the Commissioner.

Subsection (1) does not apply to a death that results from an inmate receiving medical assistance in dying, as defined in section 241.1 of the Criminal Code, in accordance with section 241.2 of that Act.
The Service shall give the Correctional Investigator, as defined in Part III, a copy of its report referred to in subsection (1).

Section.Text: The Commissioner may appoint a person or persons to investigate and report on any matter relating to the operations of the Service.
Sections 7 to 13 of the Inquiries Act apply in respect of investigations carried on under section 20

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as if the references to “commissioners” in those sections were references to the person or persons appointed under section 20; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with such other modifications as the circumstances require.

Section.Text: The Minister or a person authorized by the Minister may, subject to and in accordance with the regulations, pay compensation in respect of the death or disability of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an inmate, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person on day parole

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: that is attributable to the participation of that inmate or person in an approved program.

Section.MarginalNote: Service to obtain certain information about offender

Subsection.Text: When a person is sentenced, committed or transferred to penitentiary, the Service shall take all reasonable steps to obtain, as soon as is practicable,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: relevant information about the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: relevant information about the person’s personal history, including the person’s social, economic, criminal and young-offender history;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any reasons and recommendations relating to the sentencing or committal that are given or made by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the court that convicts, sentences or commits the person, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any court that hears an appeal from the conviction, sentence or committal;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any reports relevant to the conviction, sentence or committal that are submitted to a court mentioned in subparagraph (c)(i) or (ii); and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other information relevant to administering the sentence or committal, including existing information from the victim, the victim impact statement and the transcript of any comments made by the sentencing judge regarding parole eligibility.

Subsection.Text: Where access to the information obtained by the Service pursuant to subsection (1) is requested by the offender in writing, the offender shall be provided with access in the prescribed manner to such information as would be disclosed under the Privacy Act and the Access to Information Act.
No provision in the Privacy Act or the Access to Information Act shall operate so as to limit or prevent the Service from obtaining any information referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) to (e).
The Service shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that any information about an offender that it uses is as accurate, up to date and complete as possible.
Where an offender who has been given access to information by the Service pursuant to subsection 23(2) believes that there is an error or omission therein,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the offender may request the Service to correct that information; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the request is refused, the Service shall attach to the information a notation indicating that the offender has requested a correction and setting out the correction requested.

Section.MarginalNote: Service to give information to parole boards, etc.

Subsection.Text: The Service shall give, at the appropriate times, to the Parole Board of Canada, provincial governments, provincial parole boards, police, and any body authorized by the Service to supervise offenders, all information under its control that is relevant to release decision-making or to the supervision or surveillance of offenders.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Police to be notified of releases
Subsection.Text: Before the release of an inmate on an unescorted temporary absence, parole or statutory release, the Service shall notify all police forces that have jurisdiction at the destination of the inmate if that destination is known.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Service to give information to police in some cases
Subsection.Text: Where the Service has reasonable grounds to believe that an inmate who is about to be released by reason of the expiration of the sentence will, on release, pose a threat to any person, the Service shall, prior to the release and on a timely basis, take all reasonable steps to give the police all information under its control that is relevant to that perceived threat.
At the request of a victim of an offence committed by an offender, the Commissioner

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall disclose to the victim the following information about the offender:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the offender’s name,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the offence of which the offender was convicted and the court that convicted the offender,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of commencement and length of the sentence that the offender is serving, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: eligibility dates and review dates applicable to the offender under this Act in respect of temporary absences or parole;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may disclose to the victim any of the following information about the offender, where in the Commissioner’s opinion the interest of the victim in such disclosure clearly outweighs any invasion of the offender’s privacy that could result from the disclosure:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the offender’s age,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and location of the penitentiary in which the sentence is being served,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii.1)
Subparagraph.Text: if the offender is transferred, a summary of the reasons for the transfer and the name and location of the penitentiary in which the sentence is being served,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii.2)
Subparagraph.Text: if the offender is to be transferred to a minimum security institution as designated by Commissioner’s Directive and it is possible to notify the victim before the transfer, a summary of the reasons for the transfer and the name and location of the institution in which the sentence is to be served,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii.3)
Subparagraph.Text: the programs that were designed to address the needs of the offender and contribute to their successful reintegration into the community in which the offender is participating or has participated,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii.4)
Subparagraph.Text: the serious disciplinary offences that the offender has committed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: information pertaining to the offender’s correctional plan, including information regarding the offender’s progress towards meeting the objectives of the plan,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of any hearing for the purposes of a review under section 130,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: that the offender has been removed from Canada under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act before the expiration of the sentence, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: whether the offender is in custody and, if not, the reason why the offender is not in custody;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall disclose to the victim any of the following information about the offender, if, in the Commissioner’s opinion, the disclosure would not have a negative impact on the safety of the public:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date, if any, on which the offender is to be released on temporary absence, work release, parole or statutory release,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the conditions attached to the offender’s temporary absence, work release, parole or statutory release,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the destination of the offender on any temporary absence, work release, parole or statutory release, whether the offender will be in the vicinity of the victim while travelling to that destination and the reasons for any temporary absence; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall provide the victim with access to a photograph of the offender taken on the occurrence of the earliest of any of the following — and any subsequent photograph of the offender taken by the Service — if, in the Commissioner’s opinion, to do so would not have a negative impact on the safety of the public:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the release of the offender on unescorted temporary absence,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the offender’s work release,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the offender’s release on parole, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the offender’s release by virtue of statutory release or the expiration of the sentence.

Subsection.Text: The Commissioner shall disclose the information referred to in paragraph (1)(c) before the day on which the offender is released and, unless it is not practicable to do so, the Commissioner shall disclose it at least 14 days before that day.
The Commissioner shall disclose to the victim any changes to the information referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) to (c).

Where a person has been transferred from a penitentiary to a provincial correctional facility, the Commissioner may, at the request of a victim of an offence committed by that person, disclose to the victim the name of the province in which the provincial correctional facility is located, if in the Commissioner’s opinion the interest of the victim in such disclosure clearly outweighs any invasion of the person’s privacy that could result from the disclosure.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Disclosure of information to other persons
Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) also applies, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to a person who satisfies the Commissioner

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the person suffered physical or emotional harm, property damage or economic loss, as the result of an act of an offender, whether or not the offender was prosecuted or convicted for that act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that a complaint was made to the police or the Crown attorney, or an information was laid under the Criminal Code, in respect of that act.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (2) also applies, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to a person who satisfies the Commissioner

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the person suffered physical or emotional harm, property damage or economic loss, as the result of an act of a person referred to in subsection (2), whether or not the person referred to in subsection (2) was prosecuted or convicted for that act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that a complaint was made to the police or the Crown attorney, or an information was laid under the Criminal Code, in respect of that act.

Subsection.Text: A victim may designate a representative to whom the information referred to in subsections (1) and (2) is to be disclosed on the victim’s behalf, or to whom access to a photograph referred to in paragraph (1)(d) is to be provided. In that case, the victim shall provide the Commissioner with the representative’s contact information.

A victim who has made a request referred to in subsection (1) or (2) may inform the Commissioner in writing that they no longer want the information to be disclosed to them or access to the photograph. In that case, the Commissioner shall not contact them, or their representative, if any, unless the victim subsequently makes the request again.
The Commissioner may consider a victim to have withdrawn a request referred to in subsection (1) or (2) if the Commissioner has made reasonable efforts to contact the victim and has failed to do so.
Subsections (5) to (7) also apply, with any necessary modifications, to a person who has satisfied the Commissioner of the matters referred to in paragraphs (3)(a) and (b) or (4)(a) and (b).

The Service shall provide every victim, and every person referred to in subsection 26(3), who has registered themselves with the Service for the purposes of this section with information about its restorative justice programs and its victim-offender mediation services, and, on the victim’s or other person’s request, may take measures to provide those services.

The Service’s victim-offender mediation services are to be provided in accordance with the Commissioner’s Directives and they may be provided only with the informed consent of the participants that is voluntarily given.

Section.MarginalNote: Information to be given to offenders

Subsection.Text: Where an offender is entitled by this Part or the regulations to make representations in relation to a decision to be taken by the Service about the offender, the person or body that is to take the decision shall, subject to subsection (3), give the offender, a reasonable period before the decision is to be taken, all the information to be considered in the taking of the decision or a summary of that information.

Where an offender is entitled by this Part or the regulations to be given reasons for a decision taken by the Service about the offender, the person or body that takes the decision shall, subject to subsection (3), give the offender, forthwith after the decision is taken, all the information that was considered in the taking of the decision or a summary of that information.
Except in relation to decisions on disciplinary offences, where the Commissioner has reasonable grounds to believe that disclosure of information under subsection (1) or (2) would jeopardize

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safety of any person,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the security of a penitentiary, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of any lawful investigation,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the Commissioner may authorize the withholding from the offender of as much information as is strictly necessary in order to protect the interest identified in paragraph (a), (b) or (c).

Subsection.Text: An offender who does not have an adequate understanding of at least one of Canada’s official languages is entitled to the assistance of an interpreter

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at any hearing provided for by this Part or the regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of understanding materials provided to the offender pursuant to this section.

Section.Text: If a person is or is to be confined in a penitentiary, the Service shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that the penitentiary in which they are confined is one that provides them with an environment that contains only the necessary restrictions, taking into account

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the degree and kind of custody and control necessary for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the safety of the public,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the safety of that person and other persons in the penitentiary, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the security of the penitentiary;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: accessibility to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the person’s home community and family,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a compatible cultural environment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a compatible linguistic environment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the availability of appropriate programs and services and the person’s willingness to participate in those programs.

Section.Text: The Commissioner may authorize the transfer of a person who is sentenced, transferred or committed to a penitentiary to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: another penitentiary in accordance with the regulations made under paragraph 96(d), subject to section 28; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a provincial correctional facility or hospital in accordance with an agreement entered into under paragraph 16(1)(a) and any applicable regulations.

Subsection.Text: The Service shall assign a security classification of maximum, medium or minimum to each inmate in accordance with the regulations made under paragraph 96(z.6).
The Service shall give each inmate reasons, in writing, for assigning a particular security classification or for changing that classification.
Within the maximum and medium security classifications, the Commissioner may assign an inmate to a subclassification in accordance with the regulations made under paragraph 96(z.6).
The Commissioner or the staff member designated by the Commissioner shall give each inmate reasons, in writing, for assigning them to a subclassification or for changing that subclassification.
The purpose of administrative segregation is to maintain the security of the penitentiary or the safety of any person by not allowing an inmate to associate with other inmates.
The inmate is to be released from administrative segregation at the earliest appropriate time.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Grounds for confining inmate in administrative segregation
Subsection.Text: The institutional head may order that an inmate be confined in administrative segregation if the institutional head is satisfied that there is no reasonable alternative to administrative segregation and he or she believes on reasonable grounds that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate has acted, has attempted to act or intends to act in a manner that jeopardizes the security of the penitentiary or the safety of any person and allowing the inmate to associate with other inmates would jeopardize the security of the penitentiary or the safety of any person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: allowing the inmate to associate with other inmates would interfere with an investigation that could lead to a criminal charge or a charge under subsection 41(2) of a serious disciplinary offence; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: allowing the inmate to associate with other inmates would jeopardize the inmate’s safety.

Section.Text: All recommendations to the institutional head referred to in paragraph 33(1)(c) and all decisions by the institutional head to release or not to release an inmate from administrative segregation shall be based on the considerations set out in section 31.

Subsection.Text: Where an inmate is involuntarily confined in administrative segregation, a person or persons designated by the institutional head shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct, at the prescribed time and in the prescribed manner, a hearing to review the inmate’s case;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conduct, at prescribed times and in the prescribed manner, further regular hearings to review the inmate’s case; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: recommend to the institutional head, after the hearing mentioned in paragraph (a) and after each hearing mentioned in paragraph (b), whether or not the inmate should be released from administrative segregation.

Subsection.Text: A hearing mentioned in paragraph (1)(a) shall be conducted with the inmate present unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate is voluntarily absent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person or persons conducting the hearing believe on reasonable grounds that the inmate’s presence would jeopardize the safety of any person present at the hearing; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate seriously disrupts the hearing.

Section.MarginalNote: Where institutional head must meet with inmate
Section.Text: Where the institutional head does not intend to accept a recommendation made under section 33 to release an inmate from administrative segregation, the institutional head shall, as soon as is practicable, meet with the inmate

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to explain the reasons for not intending to accept the recommendation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to give the inmate an opportunity to make oral or written representations.

Section.Text: Where an inmate requests to be placed in, or continue in, administrative segregation and the institutional head does not intend to grant the request, the institutional head shall, as soon as is practicable, meet with the inmate

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to explain the reasons for not intending to grant the request; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to give the inmate an opportunity to make oral or written representations.

Subsection.Text: An inmate in administrative segregation shall be visited at least once every day by a registered health care professional.
The institutional head shall visit the administrative segregation area at least once every day and meet with individual inmates on request.

Section.Text: An inmate in administrative segregation has the same rights and conditions of confinement as other inmates, except for those that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can only be enjoyed in association with other inmates; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cannot be enjoyed due to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: limitations specific to the administrative segregation area, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: security requirements.

Section.Text: The purpose of the disciplinary system established by sections 40 to 44 and the regulations is to encourage inmates to conduct themselves in a manner that promotes the good order of the penitentiary, through a process that contributes to the inmates’ rehabilitation and successful reintegration into the community.
Inmates shall not be disciplined otherwise than in accordance with sections 40 to 44 and the regulations.
An inmate commits a disciplinary offence who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: disobeys a justifiable order of a staff member;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is, without authorization, in an area prohibited to inmates;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: wilfully or recklessly damages or destroys property that is not the inmate’s;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: commits theft;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is in possession of stolen property;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: is disrespectful toward a person in a manner that is likely to provoke them to be violent or toward a staff member in a manner that could undermine their authority or the authority of staff members in general;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: is abusive toward a person or intimidates them by threats that violence or other injury will be done to, or punishment inflicted on, them;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: fights with, assaults or threatens to assault another person;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: is in possession of, or deals in, contraband;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: without prior authorization, is in possession of, or deals in, an item that is not authorized by a Commissioner’s Directive or by a written order of the institutional head;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: takes an intoxicant into the inmate’s body;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: fails or refuses to provide a urine sample when demanded pursuant to section 54 or 55;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: creates or participates in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a disturbance, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other activity

ContinuedParagraph.Text: that is likely to jeopardize the security of the penitentiary;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: does anything for the purpose of escaping or assisting another inmate to escape;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: offers, gives or accepts a bribe or reward;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: without reasonable excuse, refuses to work or leaves work;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: engages in gambling;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: wilfully disobeys a written rule governing the conduct of inmates;

Paragraph.Label: (r.1)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly makes a false claim for compensation from the Crown;

Paragraph.Label: (r.2)
Paragraph.Text: throws a bodily substance towards another person; or

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: attempts to do, or assists another person to do, anything referred to in paragraphs (a) to (r).

Subsection.Text: Where a staff member believes on reasonable grounds that an inmate has committed or is committing a disciplinary offence, the staff member shall take all reasonable steps to resolve the matter informally, where possible.

Where an informal resolution is not achieved, the institutional head may, depending on the seriousness of the alleged conduct and any aggravating or mitigating factors, issue a charge of a minor disciplinary offence or a serious disciplinary offence.

Section.Text: An inmate charged with a disciplinary offence shall be given a written notice of the charge in accordance with the regulations, and the notice must state whether the charge is minor or serious.

Subsection.Text: A charge of a disciplinary offence shall be dealt with in accordance with the prescribed procedure, including a hearing conducted in the prescribed manner.
A hearing mentioned in subsection (1) shall be conducted with the inmate present unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate is voluntarily absent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person conducting the hearing believes on reasonable grounds that the inmate’s presence would jeopardize the safety of any person present at the hearing; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the inmate seriously disrupts the hearing.

Subsection.Text: The person conducting the hearing shall not find the inmate guilty unless satisfied beyond a reasonable doubt, based on the evidence presented at the hearing, that the inmate committed the disciplinary offence in question.
An inmate who is found guilty of a disciplinary offence is liable, in accordance with the regulations made under paragraphs 96(i) and (j), to one or more of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a warning or reprimand;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a loss of privileges;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an order to make restitution, including in respect of any property that is damaged or destroyed as a result of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a fine;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: performance of extra duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a serious disciplinary offence, segregation from other inmates — with or without restrictions on visits with family, friends and other persons from outside the penitentiary — for a maximum of 30 days.

Subsection.Text: A fine or restitution imposed pursuant to subsection (1) may be collected in the prescribed manner.

Section.Text: Every person commits a summary conviction offence who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is in possession of contraband beyond the visitor control point in a penitentiary;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is in possession of anything referred to in paragraph (b) or (c) of the definition “contraband” in section 2 before the visitor control point at a penitentiary;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: delivers contraband to, or receives contraband from, an inmate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: without prior authorization, delivers jewellery to, or receives jewellery from, an inmate; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: trespasses at a penitentiary.

Section.Text: In sections 47 to 67,

Definition.Text: body cavity means the rectum or vagina;
body cavity search means the physical probing of a body cavity, in the prescribed manner;
frisk search means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a manual search, or a search by technical means, of the clothed body, in the prescribed manner, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a search of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: personal possessions, including clothing, that the person may be carrying, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any coat or jacket that the person has been requested to remove,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: in accordance with any applicable regulations made under paragraph 96(l);

Definition.Text: non-intrusive search means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a search of a non-intrusive nature of the clothed body by technical means, in the prescribed manner, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a search of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: personal possessions, including clothing, that the person may be carrying, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any coat or jacket that the person has been requested to remove,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: in accordance with any applicable regulations made under paragraph 96(l);

Definition.Text: strip search means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a visual inspection of the naked body, in the prescribed manner, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a search, in accordance with any applicable regulations made under paragraph 96(l), of all clothing, things in the clothing, and other personal possessions that the person may be carrying;

Definition.Text: urinalysis means a prescribed procedure by which a person provides a urine sample, by the normal excretory process, for analysis.

Subsection.Text: A staff member may conduct routine non-intrusive searches or routine frisk searches of inmates, without individualized suspicion, in the prescribed circumstances, which circumstances must be limited to what is reasonably required for security purposes.
A person providing services of a prescribed class to the Service under a contract has the power to search that a staff member is authorized to conduct under subsection (1) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the conducting of such searches is provided for in the contract but does not constitute the person’s principal services under the contract;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the searches are reasonably related to the person’s principal services under the contract; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person has received the prescribed training to conduct such searches.

Section.Text: A staff member of the same sex as the inmate may conduct a routine strip search of an inmate, without individualized suspicion,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the prescribed circumstances, which circumstances must be limited to situations in which the inmate has been in a place where there was a likelihood of access to contraband that is capable of being hidden on or in the body; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the inmate is entering or leaving a segregation area.

Subsection.Text: Where a staff member suspects on reasonable grounds that an inmate is carrying contraband or carrying evidence relating to a disciplinary or criminal offence, the staff member may conduct a frisk search of the inmate.
A person providing services of a prescribed class to the Service under a contract has the powers of search of a staff member under subsection (1) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the conducting of such searches is provided for in the contract but does not constitute the person’s principal services under the contract;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the searches are reasonably related to the person’s principal services under the contract; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person has received the prescribed training to conduct such searches.

Subsection.Text: Where a staff member

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: believes on reasonable grounds that an inmate is carrying contraband or carrying evidence relating to a disciplinary or criminal offence, and that a strip search is necessary to find the contraband or evidence, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: satisfies the institutional head that there are reasonable grounds to so believe,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: a staff member of the same sex as the inmate may conduct a strip search of the inmate.

Subsection.Text: Where a staff member

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: satisfies the requirements of paragraph (3)(a), and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: believes on reasonable grounds that the delay that would be necessary in order to comply with paragraph (3)(b) or with the gender requirement of subsection (3) would result in danger to human life or safety or in loss or destruction of the evidence,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the staff member may conduct the strip search without complying with paragraph (3)(b) or the gender requirement of subsection (3).

Section.MarginalNote: Staff member to inform institutional head
Section.Text: Where a staff member believes on reasonable grounds that an inmate is carrying contraband in a body cavity, the staff member may not seize or attempt to seize that contraband, but shall inform the institutional head.

Where the institutional head is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that an inmate has ingested contraband or is carrying contraband in a body cavity, the institutional head may authorize in writing one or both of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the use of an X-ray machine by a qualified X-ray technician to find the contraband, if the consent of the inmate and of a qualified medical practitioner is obtained; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the detention of the inmate in a cell without plumbing fixtures, with notice to the penitentiary’s medical staff, on the expectation that the contraband will be expelled.

Section.Text: Where the institutional head is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that an inmate is carrying contraband in a body cavity and that a body cavity search is necessary in order to find or seize the contraband, the institutional head may authorize in writing a body cavity search to be conducted by a qualified medical practitioner, if the inmate’s consent is obtained.

Subsection.Text: Where the institutional head is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there exists, because of contraband, a clear and substantial danger to human life or safety or to the security of the penitentiary, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a frisk search or strip search of all the inmates in the penitentiary or any part thereof is necessary in order to seize the contraband and avert the danger,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the institutional head may authorize in writing such a search, subject to subsection (2).

Subsection.Text: A strip search authorized under subsection (1) shall be conducted in each case by a staff member of the same sex as the inmate.

Section.Text: Subject to section 56 and subsection 57(1), a staff member may demand that an inmate submit to urinalysis

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the staff member believes on reasonable grounds that the inmate has committed or is committing the disciplinary offence referred to in paragraph 40(k) and that a urine sample is necessary to provide evidence of the offence, and the staff member obtains the prior authorization of the institutional head;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: as part of a prescribed random selection urinalysis program, conducted without individualized grounds on a periodic basis and in accordance with any Commissioner’s Directives that the regulations may provide for; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where urinalysis is a prescribed requirement for participation in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a prescribed program or activity involving contact with the community, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a prescribed substance abuse treatment program.

Section.Text: Subject to section 56 and subsection 57(2), a staff member, or any other person so authorized by the Service, may demand that an offender submit to urinalysis

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at once, where the staff member or other authorized person has reasonable grounds to suspect that the offender has breached any condition of a temporary absence, work release, parole or statutory release that requires abstention from alcohol or drugs, in order to monitor the offender’s compliance with that condition; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at regular intervals, in order to monitor the offender’s compliance with any condition of a temporary absence, work release, parole or statutory release that requires abstention from alcohol or drugs.

Section.Text: Where a demand is made of an offender to submit to urinalysis pursuant to section 54 or 55, the person making the demand shall forthwith inform the offender of the basis of the demand and the consequences of non-compliance.

Subsection.Text: An inmate who is required to submit to urinalysis pursuant to paragraph 54(a) shall be given an opportunity to make representations to the institutional head before submitting the urine sample.

An offender who is required to submit to urinalysis at regular intervals pursuant to section 55 shall be given reasonable opportunities to make representations to the prescribed official in relation to the length of the intervals.

The Service may demand that an offender wear a monitoring device in order to monitor their compliance with a condition of a temporary absence, work release, parole, statutory release or long-term supervision that restricts their access to a person or a geographical area or requires them to be in a geographical area.
An offender who is required to wear a monitoring device is to be given reasonable opportunities to make representations to the prescribed official in relation to the duration of the requirement.

Section.Text: A staff member may, in the prescribed manner, conduct searches of cells and their contents in the prescribed circumstances, which circumstances must be limited to what is reasonably required for security purposes.

A staff member may conduct routine non-intrusive searches or routine frisk searches of visitors, without individualized suspicion, in the prescribed circumstances, which circumstances must be limited to what is reasonably required for security purposes.

Subsection.Text: A staff member may conduct a frisk search of a visitor where the staff member suspects on reasonable grounds that the visitor is carrying contraband or carrying other evidence relating to an offence under section 45.
Where a staff member

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: suspects on reasonable grounds that a visitor is carrying contraband or carrying other evidence relating to an offence under section 45 and believes that a strip search is necessary to find the contraband or evidence, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: satisfies the institutional head that there are reasonable grounds

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to suspect that the visitor is carrying contraband or carrying other evidence relating to an offence under section 45, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to believe that a strip search is necessary to find the contraband or evidence,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: a staff member of the same sex as the visitor may, after giving the visitor the option of voluntarily leaving the penitentiary forthwith, conduct a strip search of the visitor.

Subsection.Text: Where a staff member believes on reasonable grounds that a visitor is carrying contraband or carrying other evidence relating to an offence under section 45 and that a strip search is necessary to find the contraband or evidence,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the staff member may detain the visitor in order to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: obtain the authorization of the institutional head to conduct a strip search, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: obtain the services of the police; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the staff member satisfies the institutional head that there are reasonable grounds to believe

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that the visitor is carrying contraband or carrying other evidence relating to an offence under section 45, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: that a strip search is necessary to find the contraband or evidence,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: the institutional head may authorize a staff member of the same sex as the visitor to conduct a strip search of the visitor.

Subsection.Text: A visitor who is detained pursuant to subsection (3) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be informed promptly of the reasons for the detention; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before being searched, be given a reasonable opportunity to retain and instruct counsel without delay and be informed of that right.

Subsection.Text: A staff member may, in the prescribed manner, conduct routine searches of vehicles at a penitentiary, without individualized suspicion, in the prescribed circumstances, which circumstances must be limited to what is reasonably required for security purposes.

A staff member who believes on reasonable grounds that contraband is located in a vehicle at a penitentiary in circumstances constituting an offence under section 45 may, with prior authorization from the institutional head, search the vehicle.

Where a staff member believes on reasonable grounds that the delay that would be necessary in order to comply with the prior authorization requirement of subsection (2) would result in danger to human life or safety or the loss or destruction of the contraband, the staff member may search the vehicle without that prior authorization.
An institutional head may, in writing, authorize a staff member to search the vehicles at a penitentiary if the institutional head has reasonable grounds to believe that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is a clear and substantial danger to the security of the penitentiary or the life or safety of persons because evidence exists that there is contraband at the penitentiary or that a criminal offence is being planned or has been committed at the penitentiary; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is necessary to search the vehicles in order to locate and seize the contraband or other evidence and to avert the danger.

Section.Text: At each penitentiary, a conspicuous warning shall be posted at the entrance to the lands and at the visitor control point, stating that all visitors and vehicles at the penitentiary are subject to being searched in accordance with this Part and the regulations.

A staff member may conduct routine non-intrusive searches or routine frisk searches of other staff members, without individualized suspicion, in the prescribed circumstances, which circumstances must be limited to what is reasonably required for security purposes.

Subsection.Text: Where a staff member believes on reasonable grounds that another staff member is carrying contraband or carrying evidence relating to a criminal offence and that a frisk search or strip search is necessary to find the contraband or evidence,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the staff member may detain the other staff member in order to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: obtain the authorization of the institutional head to conduct a frisk search or strip search, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: obtain the services of the police; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the staff member satisfies the institutional head that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the other staff member is carrying contraband or carrying evidence relating to a criminal offence and that a frisk search or strip search is necessary to find the contraband or evidence, the institutional head may

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: authorize a staff member to conduct a frisk search of the other staff member, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: authorize a staff member of the same sex as the other staff member to conduct a strip search of that other staff member.

Subsection.Text: A staff member who is detained pursuant to subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be informed promptly of the reasons for the detention; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: before being searched, be given a reasonable opportunity to retain and instruct counsel without delay and be informed of that right.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 50, a staff member may seize contraband, or evidence relating to a disciplinary or criminal offence, found in the course of a search conducted pursuant to sections 47 to 64, except a body cavity search or a search described in paragraph 51(a).
A medical practitioner conducting a body cavity search may seize contraband or evidence relating to a disciplinary or criminal offence found in the course of that search.
A person conducting a search pursuant to subsection 47(2) or 49(2) may seize contraband found in the course of that search.
An employee of a community-based residential facility who is so authorized by the Service may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a frisk search of an offender in that facility, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: search an offender’s room and its contents,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: where the employee suspects on reasonable grounds that the offender is violating or has violated a condition of the offender’s parole, statutory release or temporary absence and that such a search is necessary to confirm the suspected violation.

Subsection.Text: An employee who conducts a search pursuant to subsection (1) may seize any evidence of a violation of the offender’s conditions of release found in the course of the search.
In this section, community-based residential facility means a place that provides accommodation to offenders who are on parole, statutory release or temporary absence.

Heading.TitleText: Reports Relating to Searches and Seizures

Section.Text: Reports in respect of searches conducted pursuant to sections 47 to 66, and in respect of the seizure of items in the course of those searches, must be submitted where required by regulations made under paragraph 96(o) and in accordance with those regulations.
No person shall apply an instrument of restraint to an offender as punishment.
No person shall administer, instigate, consent to or acquiesce in any cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment or punishment of an offender.

The Service shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that penitentiaries, the penitentiary environment, the living and working conditions of inmates and the working conditions of staff members are safe, healthful and free of practices that undermine a person’s sense of personal dignity.

Subsection.Text: In order to promote relationships between inmates and the community, an inmate is entitled to have reasonable contact, including visits and correspondence, with family, friends and other persons from outside the penitentiary, subject to such reasonable limits as are prescribed for protecting the security of the penitentiary or the safety of persons.
At each penitentiary, a conspicuous notice shall be posted at the visitor control point, listing the items that a visitor may have in possession beyond the visitor control point.

Where a visitor has in possession, beyond the visitor control point, an item not listed on the notice mentioned in subsection (2) without having previously obtained the permission of a staff member, a staff member may terminate or restrict the visit.

Section.Text: Every member of the House of Commons, every Senator and every judge of a court in Canada has the right to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: enter any penitentiary,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: visit any part of a penitentiary, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: visit any inmate, with the consent of the inmate,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: subject to such reasonable limits as are prescribed for protecting the security of the penitentiary or the safety of persons.

Section.Text: Inmates are entitled to reasonable opportunities to assemble peacefully and associate with other inmates within the penitentiary, subject to such reasonable limits as are prescribed for protecting the security of the penitentiary or the safety of persons.

The Service shall provide inmates with the opportunity to contribute to decisions of the Service affecting the inmate population as a whole, or affecting a group within the inmate population, except decisions relating to security matters.

An inmate is entitled to reasonable opportunities to freely and openly participate in, and express, religion or spirituality, subject to such reasonable limits as are prescribed for protecting the security of the penitentiary or the safety of persons.
The Service shall provide a range of programs designed to address the needs of offenders and contribute to their successful reintegration into the community.
Without limiting the generality of section 76, the Service shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide programs designed particularly to address the needs of female offenders; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: consult regularly about programs for female offenders with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: appropriate women’s groups, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: other appropriate persons and groups

ContinuedParagraph.Text: with expertise on, and experience in working with, female offenders.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: encouraging offenders to participate in programs provided by the Service, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: providing financial assistance to offenders to facilitate their reintegration into the community,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the Commissioner may authorize payments to offenders at rates approved by the Treasury Board.

Subsection.Text: Where an offender receives a payment referred to in subsection (1) or income from a prescribed source, the Service may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make deductions from that payment or income in accordance with regulations made under paragraph 96(z.2) and any Commissioner’s Directive; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: require that the offender pay to Her Majesty in right of Canada, in accordance with regulations made pursuant to paragraph 96(z.2.1) and as set out in a Commissioner’s Directive, an amount, not exceeding thirty per cent of the gross payment referred to in subsection (1) or gross income, for reimbursement of the costs of the offender’s food and accommodation incurred while the offender was receiving that income or payment, or for reimbursement of the costs of work-related clothing provided to the offender by the Service.

Section.Text: In sections 80 to 84,

Definition.Text: aboriginal means Indian, Inuit or Métis;
aboriginal community means a first nation, tribal council, band, community, organization or other group with a predominantly aboriginal leadership;
correctional services means services or programs for offenders, including their care and custody.

Section.Text: Without limiting the generality of section 76, the Service shall provide programs designed particularly to address the needs of aboriginal offenders.

Subsection.Text: The Minister, or a person authorized by the Minister, may enter into an agreement with an aboriginal community for the provision of correctional services to aboriginal offenders and for payment by the Minister, or by a person authorized by the Minister, in respect of the provision of those services.
Notwithstanding subsection (1), an agreement entered into under that subsection may provide for the provision of correctional services to a non-aboriginal offender.

In accordance with any agreement entered into under subsection (1), the Commissioner may transfer an offender to the care and custody of an aboriginal community, with the consent of the offender and of the aboriginal community.

The Service shall establish a National Aboriginal Advisory Committee, and may establish regional and local aboriginal advisory committees, which shall provide advice to the Service on the provision of correctional services to aboriginal offenders.
